poem:
Election Echoes

Voices rise in a Scottish dawn,
a tango of red and blue.
Sarwar speaks of preference—
as warm tea steams and ink runs dry,
the paper whispers secrets into 
a genteel, indifferent morning.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Oliver Dowden reportedly reveals preferred choice for next Tory leader – UK general election live 8.04pm BST Key event Anas Sarwar, the Scottish Labour leader, would rather see Conservative MPs than SNP MPs elected, John Swinney, Scotland’s first minister, has said after Labour rejected calls to back his party to beat Douglas Ross. SNP Westminster leader Stephen Flynn has urged Labour to back his party in Aberdeenshire North and Moray East – where the Labour". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
